questions.text: To start with, all uterine fibroids originate as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All uterine fibroids originate as intramural/interstitial.

The most common variety of fibroid is intramural/interstitial (75%), followed by submucous (15%) and subserous (10%).

  • Most common degeneration: Hyaline degeneration.
  • Degeneration starts from the central part, as the fibroid is lined by a pseudocapsule.
  • The blood vessels supplying the fibroid lie in the pseudocapsule.
  • The most vascular part of the fibroid is the peripheral part, and the least vascular is the central part.
  • Calcification starts from the periphery (Womb stone) of the fibroid.
  • The most uncommon (rarest) change in fibroid is malignant change/sarcomatous change. It occurs in 0.5% cases of fibroid.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman with a fibroid uterus develops acute pain in the abdomen with low-grade fever and mild leukocytosis at 29 weeks. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Red degeneration of fibroid is the most likely diagnosis from the features given.

  • Red degeneration of a fibroid, also known as hemorrhagic infarction, is a type of degeneration that occurs when a uterine fibroid outstrips its blood supply, leading to tissue death (necrosis).
  • It is seen mostly during pregnancy and mid-pregnancy
  • The myoma suddenly becomes acutely painful, enlarged, and tender.

Presenting complaints:

  • Acute abdominal pain
  • Vomiting
  • Malaise
  • Slight fever

Diagnosis:

  • Lab investigations show moderate leukocytosis and raised ESR
  • MRI: Shows hemorrhagic areas within the fibroid

Management:

  • Conservative treatment: Rest, analgesics, reassurance
  • Surgery is not required unless complications develop.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida lady came to the emergency department with acute abdominal pain and USG suggesting a fibroid. The most appropriate treatment would be:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Parenteral or oral analgesics would be the most appropriate treatment.

Management of red degeneration of fibroid:

  • The patient is managed conservatively.
  • Patient is put to bed rest and given analgesics (to relieve the pain), sedatives, and, if required, antibiotics.
  • If, because of a mistaken diagnosis, laparotomy is done, the abdomen is closed without doing anything.
  • Myomectomy should never be contemplated during cesarean section, as the vascularity of fibroid is increased during pregnancy (due to increased estrogen), leading to increased blood loss during cesarean section.

questions.text: What is the earliest and most common presenting feature of anterior cervical fibroid?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Frequency of urine is the earliest and most common presenting feature of anterior cervical fibroid.

  • Symptoms of cervical fibroid are predominantly due to the pressure effect on surrounding structures.
  • Anterior cervical fibroid irritates the trigone of the bladder, causing frequency of micturition or even retention due to pressure effects.
  • In the lateral cervical fibroid, vascular obstruction may lead to haemorrhoids and rarely, oedema of the legs.
  • The ureter is pushed laterally and below the tumour.
  • Posterior cervical fibroid predominantly presents with retention of urine and constipation.

choices.text: Ultrasound is ideal to confirm the diagnosis
Saline Infusion Sonography (SIS) is more sensitive in detecting any submucous fibroid
MRI is superior to USG in identifying the exact location of the myoma
CT scanning is an alternative to MRI

questions.text: Regarding imaging of uterine fibroids, all are correct except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A CT scan is not typically used for fibroid assessment because it offers poor soft tissue contrast compared to MRI and exposes the patient to unnecessary radiation.

  • Ultrasound (USG) is the first-line and ideal tool for confirming the diagnosis of uterine fibroids. (Option A)
  • Three-dimensional ultrasonography can locate fibroids accurately.
  • MRI is superior to ultrasound in determining the exact location, number, and type of fibroids, especially in complex or large uteri, but is not routinely used as it is expensive and not widely available. (Option C)
  • Saline Infusion Sonography (SIS) provides better visualisation of the endometrial cavity, making it more sensitive for detecting submucous fibroids (Option B)

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the figure.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bonney's myomectomy clamp is the instrument shown in the figure.

  • The clamp is used in a myomectomy operation.
  • It curtails the blood supply to the uterus temporarily, thereby minimising the blood loss during the operation.
  • Simultaneous bilateral clamping of the infundibulopelvic ligaments by rubber-guarded sponge holding forceps may be employed.
  • The instrument is placed at the level of the internal os, with the concavity fitting with the convexity of the symphysis pubis.
  • The round ligaments of both sides are included inside the clamp to prevent slipping of the instrument and prevent the uterus from falling back.
  • The clamp is removed after suturing the myoma bed but before closing the peritoneal layers. It is seldom used nowadays.
  • Alternative methods are: Preoperative use of GnRH analogue, and/or intraoperative use of tourniquets, vasoconstrictive agents (vasopressin) and others.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old G2P1L1 woman at 18 weeks of gestation presents with acute lower abdominal pain, low-grade fever, and elevated ESR. Ultrasound confirms the presence of a fibroid with cystic degeneration. Which of the following statements is not true regarding her condition?

A. It occurs commonly during the 2nd trimester
B. Immediate surgical intervention is needed
C. It is due to interference with the blood supply
D. Treated with analgesics
E. Treated with IV antibiotics
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Immediate surgical intervention is needed (False): Management is conservative; surgery is rarely needed unless there's suspicion of another cause (e.g., torsion, rupture).
  • Treated with IV antibiotics (False): Although fever and raised ESR may be present, it's not infectious. These signs are due to torsion and inflammation, rather than infection, so antibiotics are not indicated unless a secondary infection is suspected.

This patient is most likely experiencing red (carneous) degeneration of a uterine fibroid, a common complication during the second trimester of pregnancy.

  • A. Occurs during pregnancy: Especially common in the 2nd trimester due to rapid fibroid growth and vascular compromise.
  • C. Due to interference with the blood supply: It's caused by venous thrombosis within the periphery of the fibroid, leading to hemorrhagic infarction.
  • D. Treated with analgesics: Mainstay treatment is pain relief with NSAIDs or paracetamol.

questions.text: All are methods of managing fibroid uterus except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Radiofrequency ablation, although theoretically possible, is not a commonly used or standard method for managing a fibroid uterus. It is not widely practised or recommended due to the risk of recurrence and the availability of better alternatives.

Management of fibroids

  • The most common variety of fibroid is intramural/interstitial (75%), followed by submucous (15%) and subserous (10%).
  • To start with, all fibroids are intramural/interstitial.
  • The most common degeneration in fibroids is hyaline degeneration.
  • Degeneration starts from the central part, as the fibroid is lined by a pseudocapsule. The blood vessels supplying the fibroid lie in the pseudocapsule.
  • So the most vascular part of the fibroid is the peripheral part, and the least vascular is the central part.
  • Calcification starts from the periphery (Womb stone) of the fibroid.
  • The most uncommon (rarest) change in fibroid is malignant change/sarcomatous change.
  • It occurs in 0.5% cases of fibroid.

questions.text: Calcareous degeneration occurs most commonly in which type of fibroids?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Calcareous degeneration usually involves the subserous fibroids with small peduncles or myomas of postmenopausal women.

It is usually preceded by fatty degeneration. There is precipitation of calcium carbonate or calcium phosphate within the tumour. When the whole of the tumour is converted into a calcified mass, it is termed 'womb stone'.

Complications:

  • Torsion
  • Hemorrhage
  • Infection
  • Ascites; pseudo-Meigs syndrome (Produced by a pedunculated subserous fibroid)
  • Malignant change (rarest)

Degenerations:

  • Atrophy
  • Red degeneration
  • Hyaline degeneration (MC)
  • Fatty degeneration or calcification
  • Myxomatous degeneration
  • Cystic degeneration

Explanation:

Endometriosis is commonly associated with uterine fibroids due to its estrogen dependence, like the latter. Pelvic inflammatory disease, ovarian cancer and amenorrhea have no direct associations with uterine fibromyoma.

Diseases commonly associated with leiomyomas:

  1. Follicular cysts of the ovary: Due to hormonal imbalance in estrogen-dominant states.
  2. Endometrial hyperplasia: Caused by unopposed estrogen stimulation.
  3. Endometrial cancer: Estrogen-dependent, shares hormonal risk profile with fibroids.

questions.text: Submucosal fibroid is detected by all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Laparoscopy is not the best method for detecting submucosal fibroids.

This method is useful for detecting subserous fibroids or differentiating pedunculated fibroids from other pelvic masses, but is not ideal for detecting submucosal fibroids directly.

Explanation for other options:

Hysteroscopy (Option A): This method directly visualises the uterine cavity and is very effective for detecting and treating submucosal fibroids.

Hysterosalpingography (Option B): This radiologic technique can reveal filling defects in the uterine cavity caused by submucosal fibroids.

USG (Transabdominal) (Option C): While it is less specific for detecting submucosal fibroids compared to other methods, it can still help in identifying fibroids and their locations.

questions.text: Decreased vascularity of fibroid is seen with all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Clomiphene citrate is an ovulation induction agent; it increases gonadotropins and raises estrogen levels, which can potentially stimulate fibroid growth and vascularity.

Medical therapy for fibroids (MUD GUARD):

M - Mifepristone

  • Progesterone receptor antagonist
  • Reduces fibroid size and menstrual bleeding

U - Ulipristal acetate

  • Selective progesterone receptor modulator (SPRM)
  • Controls bleeding and reduces fibroid volume

D - Danazol/Gestrinone

  • Androgenic agents
  • Induce a hypoestrogenic state
  • Rarely used due to side effects

Are - Aromatase inhibitor (Letrozole)

  • Inhibits the conversion of androgens to estrogens
  • Reduces estrogen-driven fibroid growth

Gynae - GnRH agonists/antagonists

  • GnRH analogues cause size reduction (50%) when used for 6 months.
  • But size comes back to its previous state after the drug is withdrawn, and the hypoestrogenic state induced by GnRH-agonists causes significant loss after 6 months of therapy.

Mechanism of Action of GnRH Agonist in Fibroid Treatment:

  1. GnRH agonist is administered.
  2. Initially, causes increased secretion of FSH and LH (called the flare effect).
  3. Subsequently, there is a loss of pituitary GnRH receptor sensitivity.
  4. This leads to a decrease in LH and FSH levels.
  5. As a result, estrogen levels decrease.
  6. Ultimately, there is a reduction in the size of the fibroid.

questions.text: Management options in 27-year-old women with a 7 - 7 cm-sized fibroid:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Myomectomy is preferred over hysterectomy in young women.

Symptomatic Fibroid

Medical Management

  • It is a temporary measure, mainly used to shrink the fibroid size, improve anaemia (raise Hb) and for pre-operative preparation only (not curative)
  • OCPs/Progestins:
    • Not recommended (ASRM 2004) - may worsen fibroid symptoms (Option B)
  • Danazol/Gestrinone:
    • Can shrink fibroids and reduce bleeding
    • Not 1st line - Androgenic side effects (acne, hirsutism) limit use (Option A)

Surgical Management (Young Woman, wants fertility)

Submucous Fibroid:

  • Type 0/1: Hysteroscopic myomectomy
  • Type 2 or >5 cm: Abdominal (lap/open) myomectomy

Subserosal/Intramural Fibroid:

  • 1st line (Symptom control only - bleeding): OCPs / Progestins / Tranexamic acid
  • 2nd line (Shrink size): GnRH agonists or antagonists
  • If medical fails: UAE (Uterine artery embolisation) or HIFU
  • If refractory: Myomectomy (if family not complete), Hysterectomy (if family complete)

Asymptomatic Fibroid

  • An annual pelvic exam is sufficient
  • Annual USG only if: The uterus is too large to palpate adnexa and/or needs to be monitored for growth or complications

questions.text: All of the following are the indications for myomectomy in a case of fibroid uterus except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

From the given options, red degeneration of fibroid is managed conservatively, not by any surgery.

Explanation for other options:

Indications for Myomectomy

  1. Symptomatic fibroid in a woman desiring future fertility (e.g., menorrhagia, pelvic pain)
  2. Fibroid causing pressure symptoms like urinary frequency, retention, constipation, pelvic heaviness (Option C)
  3. Infertility attributable to fibroid, especially submucous or large intramural fibroids (Option A)
  4. Recurrent pregnancy loss (abortions) associated with fibroids (Option B)
  5. Rapidly enlarging fibroid in a young woman who wants uterine conservation
  6. Distortion of the uterine cavity affecting implantation or gestation
  7. Contraindications to hysterectomy or patient preference to preserve the uterus

All symptomatic fibroids generally require surgical management.

  • If fertility is desired, Myomectomy
  • If fertility is not desired or uterus preservation is not needed, a Hysterectomy

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady with failed medical treatment of a uterine polyp came for surgical treatment. The surgical treatment for uterine polyps can be:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All of the above surgical options can be considered for uterine polyps.

  • Endometrial polyp: Hysteroscopy and resection (best) Removal by ovum forceps.
  • In case of recurrence, and if the family has completed, uterine curettage and hysterectomy are preferred.
  • Cervical polyp: Twisting of the pedicle
  • Big fibroid in vagina: Removal of polyp by morcellation, if associated with inversion, enucleate

questions.text: A 28-year-old lady came to the OPD with abdominal pain. She was also having a USG report suggesting intramural fibroids. The least common complication of fibroids is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sarcomatous change (malignancy) is seen in 0.2-0.5% of fibroids. It is the least common complication of fibroids.

  • Sarcomas with malignant behaviour have > 10 mitoses/high power field.
  • The most common fibroid to undergo malignancy is Submucous, followed by Intramural.

Complications of fibroid:

  • Torsion
  • Hemorrhage
  • Infection
  • Ascites; pseudo-Meigs syndrome (Produced by a pedunculated subserous fibroid)
  • Malignant change (rarest)

Degenerations:

  • Atrophy
  • Red degeneration
  • Hyaline degeneration (MC)
  • Fatty degeneration or calcification
  • Myxomatous degeneration
  • Cystic degeneration

questions.text: The most common type of uterine polyp is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common uterine polyp is a mucous (endometrial/adenoma) polyp.

  • Polyps are mostly symptomless; if they become ulcerated, then features of menorrhagia/metrorrhagia are seen.
  • Most common in postmenopausal females
  • Predisposing factors: HRT, tamoxifen therapy and increased patient age
  • IOC = Hysteroscopy
  • Management: Hysteroscopy-guided polypectomy.
  • Rarely, polyps undergo malignant change (0.5%):
    • Endometrial polyp develops into adenocarcinoma
    • Fibroid polyp into sarcoma
    • Placental polyp into choriocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female came with 2 years of infertility and submucosal fibroids. She was scheduled for a myomectomy. All of the following measures reduce bleeding during myomectomy except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

OCPs (combined oral contraceptives): Along with progestins and tranexamic acid, they only provide symptomatic relief (e.g., control bleeding) but do not reduce fibroid size or vascularity. Therefore, they are not effective for reducing surgical bleeding

Multiple strategies are employed to minimise bleeding during myomectomy, especially in women undergoing fertility-preserving surgery. These include:

  • Preoperative GnRH analogues: Reduce fibroid size and vascularity (Option D)
  • Moderate Edelberg position: Enhances venous return
  • Postmenstrual timing of surgery: The Endometrium is thinnest
  • Hypotensive anaesthesia: Using agents like sodium nitroprusside
  • Intraoperative vasoconstrictive agents: e.g., vasopressin (Option C)
  • Mechanical methods like Victor Bonney's myomectomy clamp and Tourniquets to occlude uterine vessels
  • Preoperative uterine artery embolisation (UAE) (in selected cases)
  • Preoperative anaemia correction is also a preventive measure. (Option A)

questions.text: Identify the fibroid based on FIGO classification:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The fibroid shown in the figure is subserosal with a 50% intramural component. Hence, it is a type 5 fibroid according to FIGO classification.

FIGO Leiomyoma Classification System:

For hybrid leiomyomas (affecting both endometrial and serosal surfaces), two numbers are written with a hyphen.

  • First number → Relationship with endometrium
  • Second number → Relationship with serosa
